channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Olympics Are a Show Of Global Harmony. The World is Anything But.
item.description: The Winter Games, which officially open in Italy on Friday, are rooted in international cooperation. That feels out of place to some in a world where old rules no longer apply.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Olympic rings in Livigno, Italy.

item.title: Jessie Diggins is the Olympian Testing the Limits of Endurance
item.description: Jessie Diggins has become the best-ever American cross-country skier because of what she pushes her body through.
item.dc:creator: Reid Forgrave
item.media:credit: Holly Andres for The New York Times

item.title: Milan Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony: How to Watch, Timing and More
item.description: They will take place at 2 p.m. Eastern on Friday across four separate venues in Northern Italy.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
item.media:description: A training session at Livigno Snow Park in Italy on Wednesday.

item.title: Bitcoin Drops to Lowest Price Since Trump Was Elected as Crypto Faces Slump
item.description: The price of Bitcoin is now lower than when President Trump was elected in 2024, raising concerns of a new “crypto winter" in the industry.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany

item.title: Amazon’s $200 Billion Spending Plan Raises Stakes in A.I. Race
item.description: The company reported a strong holiday quarter on Thursday. But its spending, like that at other big technology companies, is starting to make investors nervous.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Emily Kask for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amazon is looking to increase automation, like at its operation in Shreveport, La.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Set for Talks in Oman
item.description: Middle Eastern diplomats see a chance for negotiations on Iran’s nuclear program but have slim hopes for progress on other U.S. demands.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A billboard at a square in Tehran last month portrayed a strike on a U.S. carrier.

item.title: Senators Clash Over Immigration Enforcement, Risking a D.H.S. Shutdown
item.description: With eight days until a deadline to keep the Department of Homeland Security running, bipartisan talks on reining in federal immigration agents’ tactics appeared to sputter before they had even gotten underway.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senators left Washington for the weekend without opening serious talks on a measure needed to keep the Department of Homeland Security running past a Feb. 13 midnight deadline.

item.title: TrumpRx, the President’s Online Drugstore, Opens for Business
item.description: TrumpRx is aimed at helping patients use their own money to buy medicines. But researchers who study drug pricing warned that many patients could pay too much if they use the site.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: The TrumpRx website is meant to be an entry point for consumers to search for their medicines and then direct them to manufacturers’ websites to buy the drugs directly.

item.title: Kennedy Makes Unfounded Claim That Keto Diet Can ‘Cure’ Schizophrenia
item.description: The claim vastly overstates preliminary research into whether the high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet might help people with the disorder, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: George Walker IV/Associated Press
item.media:description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. in Nashville on Wednesday. Mr. Kennedy has a history of promoting ideas with little to no scientific evidence to back them up.

item.title: Trump Strips Job Protections From Thousands of Federal Workers
item.description: The policy change makes it easier for the president to discipline or remove up to 50,000 employees, another push in the administration’s campaign to reshape the federal work force.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Commuters in Washington last year. More than 352,000 employees left the federal government in 2025, according to the most recent data.

item.title: The G.O.P. Senator Who Can’t Stop Thinking About the Boy ICE Detained
item.description: Katie Britt is uniquely positioned to reason with the Trump administration — when she chooses to speak up.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Kitchener
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Katie Britt of Alabama has emerged as a Republican uniquely positioned to reason with the Trump administration.

item.title: Argentina and U.S. Sign Sweeping Trade Deal as Alliance Deepens
item.description: The deal reduces reciprocal tariffs and expands quotas for key trading goods, including Argentine beef — a flashpoint for American ranchers.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with President Javier Milei of Argentina at the White House in October.

item.title: Carney Increases E.V. Investments as Trump’s Trade Policy Disrupts Canada’s Auto Industry
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced several measures Thursday aimed at making Canada a global leader in electric vehicles and rescuing an industry ravaged by U.S. trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Eduardo Lima/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada, right, visiting an auto parts plant on Thursday in Woodbridge, Ontario.

item.title: Uber Found Liable in Rape by Driver, Setting Stage for Thousands of Cases
item.description: In a federal bellwether case, the jury ordered the ride-hailing giant to pay $8.5 million to Jaylynn Dean, who said one of its drivers assaulted her in 2023.
item.dc:creator: Emily Steel
item.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jaylynn Dean at a hotel in Phoenix, where a federal jury awarded her damages on Thursday.

item.title: At Ukraine’s Request, Starlink Denies Internet Access to Russian Troops
item.description: It’s unclear what effect the change will have on Russia’s ability to wage war, but Russian military bloggers said troops were experiencing internet outages that hampered frontline communications.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier preparing a Starlink satellite internet system in the Donetsk region in 2024. Russians have been evading export restrictions to smuggle in Starlink devices and send them to the front.

item.title: Camera Was Disconnected From Nancy Guthrie’s Home Shortly Before Disappearance
item.description: The authorities confirmed that blood on Ms. Guthrie’s doorstep belonged to her. Her daughter Savannah, the “Today” anchor, released a video asking for proof that her mother is alive.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Reis Thebault
item.media:credit: Jan Sonnenmair/Getty Images
item.media:description: A sign outside Nancy Guthrie’s home on Tuesday.

item.title: Savannah Guthrie’s Video Shows a Rare and Anguished Reality
item.description: Morning show hosts have shown a vulnerable, candid side to their audiences before, but not like this.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik

item.title: What to Know About the Disappearance of Savannah Guthrie’s Mom, Nancy
item.description: Nancy Guthrie, 84, the “Today” show host’s mother, was last seen on Saturday night, the authorities said. The disappearance is being investigated as a possible kidnapping.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Sejal Govindarao/Associated Press
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers outside the home of Nancy Guthrie near Tucson, Ariz., on Monday.

item.title: New Jersey House Primary Remains Too Close to Call
item.description: Two Democrats, Analilia Mejia and Tom Malinowski, were leading in a race for their party’s nomination to replace Gov. Mikie Sherrill in the House.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully
item.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times, Brian Fraser for The New York Times
item.media:description: Analilia Mejia and Tom Malinowski were leading in a race for their party’s nomination to replace Gov. Mikie Sherrill in the House.

item.title: N.Y. House Democrats Unite to Endorse Hochul on Eve of Convention
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul is expected to receive the Democratic nomination at the party’s state convention on Friday, even as her running-mate selection has drawn some debate.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.media:credit: Liam Kennedy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul on Thursday made her first appearance with Adrienne Adams since naming her as her running mate on the Democratic ticket.

item.title: Virginia Democrats Propose New Congressional Maps Ahead of Midterms
item.description: As they appeal a ruling blocking their redistricting efforts, the state’s Democrats proposed redrawing districts in a way that would strongly favor them.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Mike Kropf/Richmond Times-Dispatch via Associated Press
item.media:description: Virginia’s proposed congressional map is one of the most significant moves by Democrats in the national redistricting arms race that has engulfed about a dozen states over the past year.

item.title: She’s Upending Japanese Politics With Two Words: ‘I’m Pregnant’
item.description: Hikaru Fujita, who’s running in Sunday’s parliamentary election, is a standout in a country where expectant mothers rarely enter national politics.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hikaru Fujita, a candidate for Parliament, in Azumino City, Nagano Prefecture, on Tuesday.

item.title: Rare Deep-Sea Giant Phantom Jellyfish Sighting Is Recorded on Video
item.description: During a dive off Argentina, scientists documented a rare jellyfish discovered a little over a century ago and seldom seen since, as well as the fish that keep it company.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: The Globalization of Canadian Rage
item.description: The world is angry. Canada’s been there all along.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Marche
item.media:credit: James Park/Reuters

item.title: America’s Rare-Earths Solution Is Hiding in Plain Sight
item.description: The real threat to a secure and sustainable supply of rare earths is not that they are scarce, but that so much is wasted.
item.dc:creator: Julie Michelle Klinger

item.title: The Louvre Thieves Dropped This Priceless Crown. Now It Looks Like This.
item.description: Empress Eugénie’s crown was left lying on the sidewalk after the Louvre Museum heist in October. The museum has now released pictures of the damage.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter

item.title: C.I.A. World Factbook Ends Publication After 6 Decades
item.description: The Factbook, a version of which dates to 1962, provided facts, figures, maps and more to generations of economists, professors, journalists and others.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk and Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times
item.media:description: The “Kryptos” sculpture in a courtyard at the C.I.A. campus. The C.I.A.’s World Factbook was shut down on Thursday.

item.title: Toronto Police Charged in Sweeping Drug and Corruption Case
item.description: After hit men targeted the home of a prison manager in June, investigators say, the schemes of a criminal network involving the police unraveled.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Jon Blacker/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: From left, Chief Myron Demkiw of the Toronto police, Chief Jim MacSween and Deputy Chief Ryan Hogan of the York Regional Police at a news conference on Thursday in Aurora, Ontario.

item.title: 12 Columbia Professors and Students Are Arrested at Anti-ICE Protest
item.description: Demonstrators, who were demanding that the university provide more protection for international students, blocked Broadway.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman and Olivia Bensimon
item.media:credit: Marco Postigo Storel for The New York Times
item.media:description: About 150 protesters called on Columbia to strengthen protections for international students.
